citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility hires contract or relief veterinarians at this time while they are actively in the process of hiring a full-time,
trained and qualified zoo animal veterinarian. Contract veterinarians are hired to cover days when their Attending
Veterinarian (AV) is not on duty. At time of this inspection, it was discovered that not all contract veterinarians had the
experience or training necessary for the handling of immobilization or anesthesia of all the species present at the facility.
Additionally, the contract veterinarians do not have their own code for access to controlled drugs at the facility. The
absence of immediate access to controlled drugs by the contract veterinarian in an emergency may delay time sensitive
needs of an animal. An acting veterinarian’s inexperience or lack of training in handling and immobilization of all animals,
along with no access to controlled drugs does not allow for the availability of appropriate personnel and services to
provide adequate veterinary care. The animal welfare regulations require that each exhibitor shall establish and maintain
programs of adequate veterinary care that include the availability of appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and
services to comply with the provisions of this subchapter.
To be corrected immediately.

On 11-02-2021, Roscoe, a 32-year-old, male Ring-tailed lemur was found deceased in the pool surrounding its exhibit
island enclosure. According to the pathology report, the pulmonary lesions were consistent with drowning as suspected
clinically. Veterinary records and the Attending Veterinarian indicated this animal had one eye and was a geriatric but
displayed no recent signs of illness. According to facility representatives, the tree in this lemur’s enclosure is typically
trimmed once or twice yearly and was trimmed or cut back by several feet on 10-19-2021.
This animal being geriatric with one eye may have potentially been negatively impacted by the amount of tree trimming.
Failure to ensure an enclosure is appropriately and safely designed or constructed so that it is structurally sound for the
species of nonhuman primate housed with consideration of the individual animal’s abilities or limitations, may lead to
serious injury or death.
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman
primates contained in them and must be kept in good repair to protect the nonhuman primate from injury, contain the
animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
Correct from this time forward.

According to facility records, on 09-06-2021, Rafael, a male, Meerkat was unable to be called to his night quarters at the
end of the day. At this time a supervisor began efforts to locate this animal within the exhibit. The next day extensive
efforts to locate the Meerkat were also unsuccessful and a possible “Code Red” (animal escape) notification was given to
alert the staff of the situation. On 09-08, the mammal curator located the body of the meerkat in the exhibit a few feet
away from a termite mound and noted it was deceased. The records state that although no evidence of burrowing near
the termite mound was found, it seemed the meerkat had dug its way down to the bottom and got trapped. Necropsy
records were supportive of asphyxiation from entrapment as cause of death.
Failure to ensure an enclosure is structurally sound, appropriately designed, and maintained in good repair or condition
for the species maintained may lead to injury or death. A system must be in place to ensure indoor and outdoor housing
facilities are structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the
animals.
Prior to this inspection, the facility has taken appropriate corrective actions by making safety modifications to the design of
this exhibit.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility hires contract or relief veterinarians at this time while they are actively in the process of hiring a full-time, 
trained and qualified zoo animal veterinarian. Contract veterinarians are hired to cover days when their Attending 
Veterinarian (AV) is not on duty. At time of this inspection, it was discovered that not all contract veterinarians had the 
experience or training necessary for the handling of immobilization or anesthesia of all the species present at the facility. 
Additionally, the contract veterinarians do not have their own code for access to controlled drugs at the facility. The 
absence of immediate access to controlled drugs by the contract veterinarian in an emergency may delay time sensitive 
needs of an animal. An acting veterinarian’s inexperience or lack of training in handling and immobilization of all animals, 
along with no access to controlled drugs does not allow for the availability of appropriate personnel and services to 
provide adequate veterinary care. The animal welfare regulations require that each exhibitor shall establish and maintain 
programs of adequate veterinary care that include the availability of appropriate facilities, personnel, equipment, and 
services to comply with the provisions of this subchapter.  
To be corrected immediately. 
3.75(a)  Critical
   
Housing facilities, general.

On 11-02-2021, Roscoe, a 32-year-old, male Ring-tailed lemur was found deceased in the pool surrounding its exhibit 
island enclosure.  According to the pathology report, the pulmonary lesions were consistent with drowning as suspected 
clinically. Veterinary records and the Attending Veterinarian indicated this animal had one eye and was a geriatric but 
displayed no recent signs of illness.  According to facility representatives, the tree in this lemur’s enclosure is typically 
trimmed once or twice yearly and was trimmed or cut back by several feet on 10-19-2021.   
This animal being geriatric with one eye may have potentially been negatively impacted by the amount of tree trimming. 
Failure to ensure an enclosure is appropriately and safely designed or constructed so that it is structurally sound for the 
species of nonhuman primate housed with consideration of the individual animal’s abilities or limitations, may lead to 
serious injury or death.   
Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman 
primates contained in them and must be kept in good repair to protect the nonhuman primate from injury, contain the 
animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. 
Correct from this time forward. 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
According to facility records, on 09-06-2021, Rafael, a male, Meerkat was unable to be called to his night quarters at the 
end of the day. At this time a supervisor began efforts to locate this animal within the exhibit. The next day extensive 
efforts to locate the Meerkat were also unsuccessful and a possible “Code Red” (animal escape) notification was given to 
alert the staff of the situation.  On 09-08, the mammal curator located the body of the meerkat in the exhibit a few feet 
away from a termite mound and noted it was deceased.  The records state that although no evidence of burrowing near 
the termite mound was found, it seemed the meerkat had dug its way down to the bottom and got trapped.  Necropsy 
records were supportive of asphyxiation from entrapment as cause of death.

Failure to ensure an enclosure is structurally sound, appropriately designed, and maintained in good repair or condition 
for the species maintained may lead to injury or death. A system must be in place to ensure indoor and outdoor housing 
facilities are structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the 
animals. 
Prior to this inspection, the facility has taken appropriate corrective actions by making safety modifications to the design of 
this exhibit. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
End Section

species.common: AFRICAN HUNTING DOG / AFRICAN WILD DOG
DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
